typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the ninth week of the course!

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 12 Introduction, and Chapter 12, Sections 12.1 to 12.7) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.

It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

nodes.title: Attitude and Persuasion Question Set (Andrew Cao)
Attitudes of Adolescents Towards Life and Self (Andrew Cao)

typeData.textContent:
Sometimes when someone is bullied, people might say, “if you are not wrong, why do others only bully you?”

When someone is sexually harassed, people might say, “you're the one who dressed like this, and you deserve it.”

When something is damaged by someone else, people might say, “You're the one who didn't take care of it, so you can’t blame others.”

Such phenomena often happen in our lives. It is called “Victim-Blaming”. Why do people always blame the victim?

Sherry Hamby, a professor of psychology at the University of the South gave her own opinion. “I think the biggest factor that promotes victim-blaming is something called the “Just-World Hypothesis”. It’s this idea that people deserve what happens to them. There’s just a really strong need to believe that we all deserve our outcomes and consequences.”

Melvin J. Lerner, a social psychologist, conducted an experiment in the 1960s in which participants were asked to observe how others were shocked without making a mistake. Lerner observed that when participants found they could do nothing but just watching others being shocked, they began to belittle the victim. For example, they declared that the person being shocked was a bad person, even though the participants did not know who the person was.

Lerner argued that this is because one's inability to cope with the suffering of others drains the sense of security and controllability that participants have built up through the “Just-World Hypothesis” away.

The hypothesis suggests that people who tend to blame the victim fall into a fallacy of logic. They assume that the world is perfectly just, so disasters won’t happen to people for no reason, and that they are hurt because the victim made mistakes.

linkMetadata.title: Inoculation Theory – PSYC 102 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Since a presentation that prevents both sides of the argument is generally more persuasive than a one-sided argument, it is often more effective as a propaganda technique to use a two-sided refutational presentation. In fact, it tends to increase the audience’s resistance to subsequent counterpropaganda; this would allow the inoculation effect to be politically useful. For example, policymakers’ attempts to shield Americans from the communist ideologies during the Cold war should not have been to introduce mandatory public school courses on “patriotism and Americanism”, but rather, to teach even-handed courses on Communism that challenge their belief in democracy. As evidenced by research, this would not make them more vulnerable to Communist propaganda but would more effectively build resistance to its ideologies.

typeData.textContent:
There have been many uses and references to the Stanford Prison Experiment in the media. Veronica Mars, which was an American TV show that in 2007, had aired an episode were a professor was doing research, and had students participate in an experiment that took place in a prison, and it went south. It was not a terrible representation of the actual experiment; however, it was flawed. A movie, trailer is tagged here, about the original experiment does a way better job at accurately describing the experiment, and the fall out.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=145&v=7LviGTHud5w&feature=emb_logo

Delving into week 9, we are introduced to the topic of pro-social behavior,  and one of the new terms the textbook comes across is the idea of homophily. This is the “tendency for people to form social networks, including friendships, marriage, business relationships, and many other types of relationships, with others who are similar” (McPherson et al., 2001).

An example for homophily and the application of it would be religious groups. Church gatherings would have the ability to bring people with the same morals and ideologies together. Similarly, school clubs and teams often are made as a result of like-minded people wanting to work together. 

Although the idea of connecting with people like oneself seems like a no-brainer good idea, there are some real world risks to only surround yourself with like-minded people. 

Learning
Being surrounded by people only like you, opportunities for learning may be diminished.  This may be not having the exposure to different interests and entertainment, (music genres, games, sports, etc) missing out on different businesses and work (work relationships), or even missing out on learning about different cultures and beliefs due to racial homophily. Homophily can impact views on our world, general knowledge, and opinions.

Simplifying and Aggression

With the idea of homophily preventing someone from being informed about certain topics and lifestyles, being surrounded by a homogenized group of people may lead to a “us” and “them” way of thinking. This idea can clearly be seen in US politics, where the existence of only two political parties provides impacts of homophily, red vs blue. In our case, homophily exists in the form of individuals surrounding themselves with people of the same political stance. Because of their politically homogenized social circles, people see the other political stances as the enemy, as each side ignores the other despite important issues needing to be discussed. 

Below is a small article that goes more into the specifics of how homophily is present on social media: 

https://medium.com/@alisabethtullo/dangers-of-homophily-in-social-media-1e7d13ebe138#:~:text=So%20while%20homophily%20may%20lead,even%20been%20linked%20to%20terrorism.

nodes.title: Internal vs External Locus of Control (Coby Zamoranos)
Conformity (Kenji Wong)
nodes.description: Examining how politicians use the idea of conformity to manipulate people.

typeData.textContent:
(The following node might be politically sensitive and people might disagree with my views. But I still want to share my thoughts as I believe it is important for us to hear different voices. I HAVE NO MEANS TO OFFEND ANYONE!)

According to the textbook, conformity is “the change in a person’s behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group.” A classical example of conformity/ obedience will be the famous Zimbardo experiment, also known as the Stanford prison experiment. The conclusion of that experiment revealed that people will readily conform to the social roles they are expected to play, especially if the roles are as strongly stereotypical as those of the prison guards. In this node, I will examine how politicians use this theory to segregate and manipulate people into fighting with each other and I will use the example of Nazis, and the HK police.

During WWII, Hitler dehumanized Jews as rats and brutally slaughtered millions of Jews and while looking into this painful history, I pounded the reasons behind his followers blindly listening to Hitler and conforming to his orders. I personally do not believe that all or even most of his followers had such a strong hatred towards Jews, which they would be obedient towards unreasonable orders such as manslaughtering. However, when comparing this to the recent HK protest and police brutality, things seemed to make more sense to me. I think that it all comes down to the significance of dehumanization, conformity, and power. Politicians first dehumanized the group of individuals, which are threats to the politicians. By referring Jews as rats, and the HK protesters as cockroaches, harming or even killing them seemed to be justifiable, especially when they are compared to pests. The next step would be conformity and it is achieved by segregation people and giving them certain powers. For instance, if you are one of the police officers, even if you have opinions towards the harming of people, most likely you are not going to voice out since the consequences of voicing out might lead to you losing the jobs and/or being isolated by the rest of the group. And as humans, we are group animals, which means we desire and feel comfortable being in a group. When we are within a certain group, we have to conform to the ideologies of that group, even if some of them strongly oppose your own. 

(Again, all of the above statements are just my own thoughts. I understand that people might disagree with my reasonings, but please respect my own thoughts. Thank you.)

Our tapestry contribution, exploring subtopics related to conformity.

By David Manuel & Nick Wong

nodes.title: Week 9 - Conformity, Compliance and Obedience (Sharon Sun)

typeData.textContent:
In 1972, the social psychologist by the name of Irving Janis coined the term “Groupthink” and defined it as a phenomenon that occurs when individuals in a group modify their opinions to align with their belief of the group consensus (Yaline, 2018). However, due to group pressures and the deterioration of mental efficacy and moral judgement, Groupthink often leads to faulty decisions. As such, the group as a whole would tend to make more extreme decisions that an individual on their own would not perform. 

One of the symptoms of this phenomenon is the illusion of invulnerability or invincibility, whereby the individuals are overly optimistic of the situation and thus, take extreme risk (Yaline, 2018). Another symptom of Groupthink is collective rationalization. This is when members discredit warnings that are contrary to the group’s beliefs (Yaline, 2018). Additionally, group members believe that their course of action is morally right and just which is represented by the symptom of belief in inherit morality (Yaline, 2018). Stereotyped views of out-groups is another a symptom where individuals hold negative attitudes towards others with differing viewpoints (Yaline, 2018). In addition to their negative attitudes, group members apply direct pressure on dissenters (Yaline, 2018). This symptom is apparent when the group views individuals with opposing opinions of their commitment as disloyal (Yaline, 2018). This leads to self-censorship, whereby members withhold their dissenting views and opinions to avoid appearing as disloyal (Yaline, 2018). Furthermore, group members exemplify symptoms of illusions of unanimity and falsely perceive that everyone in the group has reached a consensus (Yaline, 2018). The last symptom is when mind guards are appointed, which means that members appoint themselves to roles that involve safeguarding the group from adverse information that would alter the group’s cohesion and compliancy (Yaline, 2018). Janis concluded that if these conditions exist, there is a reasonable chance that Groupthink may occur due to the perceived cohesiveness among its members (Yaline, 2018). 

In order to avoid Groupthink, members must apply critical thinking and deductive reasoning skills to analyze the situation appropriately (Yaline, 2018). Although resisting conformity can be difficult, recognizing one’s own moral values and asking the appropriate questions to confirm what the right course of action is will prevent the negative effects of Groupthink. Furthermore, it is important to recognize the symptoms of Groupthink, use factual-based knowledge, and limit personal confirmation biases to decrease the likelihood of this phenomenon occurring. 

Reference 
Valine, Y. A. (2018). Why cultures fail: The power and risk of Groupthink. Journal of Risk Management in Financial Institutions, 11(4), 301–307.

nodes.title: Solomon Asch's Experiment on Conformity (Josh Li)
Quiz on Conformation and Groupthink (Josh Li)
Relating the Holocaust to Stanley Milgram’s Obedience Experiment (Allyssa Paulino)

typeData.textContent:
Obedience is defined as a form of compliance that occurs when people follow direct commands, usually from some authority. People often comply because they are concerned about consequences if they do not.

Most of us have experienced obedience as children and students, in many different environments. The first thing that comes to mind is with parents at home. It’s not uncommon for children to be expected to obey their parents. As children, we often obey our parents so as to try and avoid negative consequences such as being sent to our rooms or being grounded. When we reach adolescence, we tend to crave autonomy and drift away from the absolute parental compliance that was prevalent during childhood.

As we distance ourselves somewhat from the authority of our parents, we are faced with new authority figures in high school and new social norms, which we are further expected to obey. We encounter teachers, coaches, group leaders, and are exposed to norms decided by classmates, peers, and friend groups. We also become more cognizant of the world, society, and institutions that may demand our obedience. For example, many teens get their first job and are introduced to structures of organizational authority in the workplace. Bosses, managers, and supervisors become new figures to obey.

Throughout our lives and as we develop, the expectations for our obedience is continuously evolving with us. From our parents as children, to teachers as adolescents, to bosses as workers and to laws as part of a society. It may be impossible to achieve true autonomy, since there will always be some authority to which we must obey in order to avoid consequences in life.

By Julia Gorrie and Bi Yu Li

nodes.title: Unconscious Bias in the Workplace (Cindy Hsu) [psychos]

typeData.textContent:
Attribution theory has real-life impacts in the workplace. Unfortunately, it affects our behavior towards others unconsciously, and usually works against marginalized groups of people. It can show up in interviewing decisions, work distribution, performance reviews, and even in mundane conversation. Being aware of its effects when interacting with others can help in creating a safe and inclusive work environment. Some types of unconscious bias include:

1) halo/horn effect: When our impression of someone affects what we judge their competence or character to be (e.g. we might assume someone who looks conventionally attractive to be better at a job). Halo effect refers to positive attributions while horn effect refers to the negative attribution variant.

2) affinity bias: We often attribute positive personality traits to people we identify as similar to ourselves (or in our "in-group"). When applied to hiring and management this can lead to a preference for candidates of a specific race or background (e.g. school), irrespective of their actual skill.

3) gender bias: Women are often attributed to being family-oriented, which may lead to employers trying to pry into their personal lives. They may also be seen as less competent than their male counterparts, creating a "glass ceiling" for career advancement. This means it becomes difficult to be promoted to senior or executive positions.

Sources
https://www.forbes.com/sites/pragyaagarwaleurope/2018/10/19/how-can-bias-during-interviews-affect-recruitment-in-your-organisation/#66718ab1951a
https://www.ciphr.com/features/unconscious-bias-in-the-workplace/

What is it attribution theory ?
•	it is to describe why people are behaving the way they are. 
•	attribute people's behaviour to their environment or current situation or to their personal dispositions.
Attribute people's behaviour to their environment is called external factors.
Attribute people's behaviour to their personal dispositions is called internal factors.
Fundamental attribution error :When people fail to recognize when the behavior of another is due to situational variables, and thus to the person’s state.
EXAMPLE...
When your boyfriend  returns home from work, and upon opening the front door his girlfriend happily greets him and ask about his day. Instead of happily answering  his girlfriend , he yells at her, “Leave me alone!” Why did he yell at his girlfriend? In this case of  fundamental attribution error will be saying that he is a mean, angry, or unfriendly.
The actor-observer bias is the phenomenon of attributing other people’s behavior to internal factors (fundamental attribution error) while attributing our own behaviour to situational forces.
 
Self-service bias is that people attribute their successes to internal factors and our failures to external factors.
Example: If people get a great job, people think that they were particularly well qualified for the position, but if they could not get that same great job, they would think that the day was a particularly bad one to have interview on.
There are two different types of ways to explain people's behaviour
Externalizers: People who believe that events or situations are because of the factors beyond their personal control. 
Internalizers: People who take responsibility for their own actions, or who feel they have the power to do something about the event or situation. 
Work cited
Opentax https://openstax.org/books/psychology/pages/12-1-what-is-social-psychology

Self-Fulfilling PropheSelf-Fulfilling Prophecies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)cies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
Self-fulfilling prophecies is the idea in which the expectation of a person’s behaviour affects the actions towards them. This is prevalent in cases where a false expectation is reaffirmed until it becomes true due to actions of the individuals. Similar to the confirmation bias, this can be detrimental to a study in many cases. 

A study by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1992) showed that when teachers were told that some of their students in their class had significantly higher IQ and that they would perform better than their peers, by the end of the year, these students who actually were average, did turn out to perform better in the end.[1]

In cases, it is not only just one-sided reaffirmation. One study showed that in a workplace setting, a leader’s expectations of an employee’s behaviour can influence the employee’s expectation of the leader’s behaviour as well.[2] This feedback loop reaffirms both expectations until both become true.

1. Rosenthal, Robert; Jacobson, Lenore (1992). Pygmalion in the classroom: teacher expectation and pupils' intellectual development. ISBN 978-1904424062.
2. Bezuijen, Xander M.; Berg, Peter T.; Dam, Karen; Thierry, Henk (2009). Pygmalion and Employee Learning: The Role of Leader Behaviors. Journal of Management. 35 (5): 1248–1267. doi:10.1177/0149206308329966.

nodes.title: Self-Fulfilling Prophecies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
Self-fulfilling prophecies is the idea in which the expectation of a person’s behaviour affects the actions towards them. This is prevalent in cases where a false expectation is reaffirmed until it becomes true due to actions of the individuals. Similar to the confirmation bias, this can be detrimental to a study in many cases. 

A study by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1992) showed that when teachers were told that some of their students in their class had significantly higher IQ and that they would perform better than their peers, by the end of the year, these students who actually were average, did turn out to perform better in the end.[1]

In cases, it is not only just one-sided reaffirmation. One study showed that in a workplace setting, a leader’s expectations of an employee’s behaviour can influence the employee’s expectation of the leader’s behaviour as well.[2] This feedback loop reaffirms both expectations until both become true.

1. Rosenthal, Robert; Jacobson, Lenore (1992). Pygmalion in the classroom: teacher expectation and pupils' intellectual development. ISBN 978-1904424062.
2. Bezuijen, Xander M.; Berg, Peter T.; Dam, Karen; Thierry, Henk (2009). Pygmalion and Employee Learning: The Role of Leader Behaviors. Journal of Management. 35 (5): 1248–1267. doi:10.1177/0149206308329966.

nodes.title: Conformity-based Preference Falsification and Psychological Studies (David Manuel)
nodes.description: Explores the ways in which preference falsification (rooted in pressure to conform) may lead to confounding effects in psychological studies.

linkMetadata.title: Conformity-based Preference Falsification and Psychological Studies – PSYC 102 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). 7.5 Measures of Intelligence. In . Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.

typeData.textContent:
Preference falsification is a term that the economist Timur Kuran (1997) proposed in his book __Private Truths Public Lies__.
Kuran uses the term to refer to instances in which individuals falsify their preferences due to conformity. In deference to group norms, and perhaps out of fear of being excluded, individuals might conform by falsifying their preferences. 
Preference falsification appears to be a behavior that is based on our tendency towards conformity.
What might the consequences of preference falsification be?
One area in which preference falsification could lead to negative outcomes is in psychological studies (or studies in the social sciences more broadly).
Our text (Spielman et al, 2018) states that conformity is impacted by whether or not our actions are taking place publicly or privately.
    “Research shows that the size of the majority, the presence of another dissenter, and the public or relatively private nature of responses are key influences on conformity.”
How might one consider designing a study so as to minimize the potential that individuals will falsify their preferences based on conformity?
One solution might be to design a study based on surveys that participants fill out in the privacy of their own homes, rather than having a participant answer questions in a group setting or with an administrator synchronously present.
However, as we learned in chapter 2 (about research methods), people do not necessarily answer surveys accurately (Spielman et al, 2018). Some people falsify their preferences on surveys (perhaps in part due to conformity) even when they are filling their surveys out privately. It’s possible that an individual might feel pressured to answer even anonymous questions based on what they perceive to be the group norms.
Since all studies anonymize the data received from participants, hopefully the effects of potential preference falsification on surveys can be minimized. Ideally participants will act based on the fact that they are answering surveys confidentially, and will therefore feel free to represent their preferences accurately when answering surveys.
However, the problem of preference falsification due to conformity might be more difficult to control for when using other research method. If our research method involves people interacting in-person/synchronously, the potential for the confounding effects of conformity to come into play may be higher as the sense of anonymity is at least partially lost. The potentially confounding effects of preference falsification might be of an issue in some experimental designs, in designs that involve face to face interaction, and in designs where multiple participants are simultaneously present.
References
Kuran, T. (1997). __Private Truths, public lies: The social consequences of preference falsification__. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). 7.5 Measures of Intelligence. In __Psychology__. Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.

Non-conformity
Reactance theory
Although many obey and conform to the social norms around us, some might not. The non-conformists are the ones who knowingly act against the situational norm due to their personal opinion. Neither normative or informational influence affected their attitude towards a certain topic. This could be due to many psychological factors, such as having faith, being confident, or simply being stubborn. It is important to note that non-conformity is different from having another opinion. It is a refusal to abide by conventional expectations.

Reactance

What does it take for someone to not conform? When do people not obey on expectations? When parents instruct their teens to do chores, most teens would not like their instructions even though they were going to do them anyways. No one likes being predicted and told what to do, it feels like the freedom of choice is being threatened. As a result, the person might not conform and intentionally delays the chores even though it is what was planned. This act displays the reactance theory. Reactance is defined as unpleasant motivational arousal that emerges when people experience a threat to or loss of their free behaviors(1). The amount of reactance increases as greater freedom is perceived to be threatened. Generally, it is often accompanied by anger, annoyance, and aggressiveness. Measuring a person’s reactance as a trait requires the revised Hong’s Psychological Reactance Scale. Hong & Fredda compose the eleven questions with the following four factors in mind(2).
- Emotional response to an unrestricted choice
- Reaction to compliance
- Resisting influence from others
- Resistance to advice & recommendations


Resisting reactance

Reactance often works against the role of the persuader. If we are the persuader, what should we do to prevent it? A study in France was done in 2000 by Pascual and Gueguen to discover the effectiveness of the “But you are free” technique. They went around in a mall in France and begged for coins(3). They asked the strangers in two different ways.
- “Sorry, Madam/Sir, would you have some coins to take the bus, please?”
- “Sorry, Madam/Sir, would you have some coins to take the bus, please? But you are free to accept or to refuse.”
The total amount of money they have received with the latter wording doubled the former. The experiment attacked the fact that people are more likely to say no if their freedom is threatened, they purposely minimize that threat towards freedom with the phrase “But you are free to accept or refuse”.

(1)Steindl, Christina et al. “Understanding Psychological Reactance: New Developments and Findings.” Zeitschrift fur Psychologie vol. 223,4 (2015): 205-214. doi:10.1027/2151-2604/a000222

(2)Hong, Sung-Mook, and Salvatora Faedda. “Refinement of the Hong Psychological Reactance Scale.” Educational and Psychological Measurement, vol. 56, no. 1, Feb. 1996, pp. 173–182, doi:10.1177/0013164496056001014.

(3)Christopher J. Carpenter (2013) A Meta-Analysis of the Effectiveness of the “But You Are Free” Compliance-Gaining Technique, Communication Studies, 64:1, 6-17, DOI: 10.1080/10510974.2012.727941
